ftbquests.chapter.10_podeeeer.title: 10. POWEEEEER
ftbquests.chapter.18_pacto_final.title: 18. Final Pact
ftbquests.chapter.4_mekanologia.quest1.d: Steel. Glass. Hermetic tubes. Redstone. None of that matters.
If you were waiting for the future… well, it started when you pressed this block into the ground.
But even if that sounds amazing, Mekanism is a sprawling technology that should be dissected in parts. How about we start from the basics?
&7&o— Congrats, you made a box. But a box that stares back.&r&r
What you’re holding isn’t a box — it’s the negation of chaos.
The Steel Casing is the divider of eras. No smoke, no creaking levers.
Only cold light, impassive interfaces, and the uncomfortable feeling that
someone overthought how this should work.
The Precision Matrix embedded in its heart is a direct insult to the rusticity of Immersive Engineering — every weld line on it seems to ask:
“Was this really what you thought technology was?”
From here, it’s no longer about operating machines. You’re going to orchestrate protocols.
Gases will come. Chambers will be pressurized. Temperature will be a variable,
For a long time, doubling ores was an exercise in space, noise, and patience. Platforms trembling, hammers pounding, gears screaming in industrial agony. It was beautiful, in an archaic way. And then, this appeared.

The Enrichment Chamber is everything the old Immersive Crusher isn’t: compact, quiet, scalable. While that mechanical mammoth demanded entire yards and constant maintenance, this chamber does the same job — better — in the footprint of a door.

It’s an elegant break with the past, but a hard one to ignore. Because, let’s be honest, the old Crusher had personality. And of course, don’t forget it also makes your ores go further in metallurgy. Win–win.
&7&o— It’s still out there, standing… huge… useless… but beautiful, isn’t it?&r&r
You’ve already smelted, heated, broken, and reconstituted alloys as far as your machines would let you. But the Osmium Compressor does something different: it applies pressure with purpose.
Here, osmium isn’t just fuel — it’s a catalyst. It’s a signature.
Each ingot produced carries the weight of a resource that refuses to be reduced to a mere percentage. It’s a machine with a high cost and even higher promises. And it delivers.
And yes, if you ask me, I’ll always say every machine is different from all the others. It’s a special way of making them feel loved.
&7&o— The secret is in the compression. And in the audacity to charge so much for a single ingot.&r&r
ftbquests.chapter.4_mekanologia.quest2.d: The Metallurgic Infuser marks the end of metallurgy as you knew it. It doesn’t heat or fuse — it persuades. Redstone, coal, diamond… each substance offers more than its weight. They offer meaning. Metal ceases to be a resource and becomes a vehicle for ideas.

This machine doesn’t craft alloys; it creates components with memory, pieces that carry encoded intentions. It’s the birth of programmed efficiency, of obedient matter. From now on, your circuits won’t just be technical — they’ll be ideological.
&7&o— An infuser is a sort of industrial philosopher. It just accepts coal as an argument.&r&r
A metal that shines. So far, nothing new. But this one doesn’t shine from combustion or incandescence. It shines because it was convinced to — because someone infused it with purpose and enough osmium to become useful.

Refined Glowstone is your gateway to alloys that seem magical but charge like military tech. It floats. It emits light. It works. It’s hard not to respect that, even if your first reaction was “that’s gold with an ego.”
&7&o— Refined glowstone: for those who thought the sun needed a portable, unstable version.&r&r
You thought of calling it Osgloglas. We admit: that would be poetic.
A nod to the past, to that mythical PlusTic alloy beloved by obsessive miners and pickaxes that dug faster than sanity.
But this is another material. It shines differently. It vibrates.
Osgloglium is our version — toxic, radioactive, extremely efficient, and absurdly hard to justify in small projects. It exists for those who’ve gotten over the fear of overdoing it.
And between us, with that name… of course it’ll end up on an anvil. Repeatedly.
&7&o— We could’ve called it Esgloglas, but… no. This one has a personality of its own. And radiation.&r&r
Osgloglium: the name that almost was
ftbquests.chapter.4_mekanologia.quest3.d: You created your first circuit. Simple, obedient, almost innocent. A small board that knows how to turn on and off, but doesn’t understand why. And maybe that’s for the best. Functional ignorance is what keeps any system flowing without awkward questions.
&7&o— In computing terms, it’s an intern. Cheap, tireless, and replaceable.&r&r
There are no visible pistons, no exposed gears. No three-story structure shaking under its own weight.
Mekanism’s Crusher does everything its predecessor did — just without looking like a heavy engineering experiment funded by a crumbling empire.

It’s clean, efficient, connectable. Instead of honoring the tradition of mechanical brutality, it simply delivers results. This is the future. Even if, deep down, you still hear the hammers of the old Crusher pounding in your memory.
&7&o— Growing up is realizing you don’t need 400 blocks of steel to crush a rock. Doesn’t mean you won’t miss them.&r&r
The Machine That Beat Brute Force
You took three materials with wills of their own — raw quartz, refined obsidian, and the promising Inductive Alloy — and forced them to collaborate. The result was something translucent, strong, and conductive. A real breakthrough… insofar as breakthroughs stand being called that.

Refined Quartz appears as the dream of perfect integration: lightness, strength, and energy in balance. But soon you notice it doesn’t shine as much as promised. The Inductive Alloy, sold as the apex of conduction, here shows itself as one more midpoint with good marketing.
Still, the material has value. It serves. It responds. And above all, it survives systems that would break any other compound. That’s already more than most can say.
&7&o— The problem with calling something an “apex” is that someone always shows up with one more step.&r&r
You’ve broken obsidian with a pickaxe. Now you’re about to use it as the basis for armaments.
Refined Obsidian isn’t just tough — it defies common sense by being refinable.
Nothing this hard should be processable, and yet here you are, compressing volcanic rock as if it were aluminum.
This material doesn’t want to yield. And for that very reason, it’s worth every second of effort.
&7&o— The ultimate armor begins where the geologist’s patience ends.&r&r
ftbquests.chapter.4_mekanologia.quest4.d: A bit of Infused Alloy and the board already starts thinking it has a personality. It recognizes patterns, anticipates commands, and even optimizes flows — within the limits you programmed, of course. Deep down, it just wants to please. And work.
&7&o— It still obeys. But sometimes it silently asks “why?”&r&r
This is the convergence point. Cables align. Interfaces find direction. Data flows find their rhythm. The ME Controller isn’t just a central piece — it’s the first component in your network that understands that you don’t understand anything.

In practice, it allows multiple channels to coexist. It expands your connection capacity. It divides logic and infrastructure. It turns a bundle of functional cables into a scalable system, with 32 channels per face, parallel connections, and modular branches.
If before you were just connecting things, now you’re managing paths.

Keep in mind it loves friends. If 6 faces and 182 channels seem too little, you can always add more. But don’t forget, it’s the social type that still wants order at its party. It will only accept more blocks if the shape is valid, always arranging itself in cuboid forms and directly connected — horseshoes, rectangles, edges, squares, corners, cubes, or a wild tesseract, take your pick. And don’t worry, if it doesn’t like the shape you chose, it will make that &4&lvery clear&r&r

When you place it, everything feels more serious. More legitimate. More technical. What used to be a hacky mess of loose terminals now becomes a real system. It doesn’t do much on its own, of course. But it commands respect. And power consumption.
It’s the illusion of control — the name doesn’t deny it — in a sea of connections you’ll still mess up while trying to be organized.
But don’t worry. That’s what most systems do: simulate order long enough for no one to question it anymore.
&7&o— Creating an ME Controller is like declaring you know what you’re doing. It’s a lie, but it helps the cables behave.&r&r
ftbquests.chapter.4_mekanologia.quest5.d: Every empire starts with a solid foundation, but yours will be built with something more flexible: metallic obedience. Infused Alloy is your first successful experiment in material submission. A piece of iron, convinced by redstone it was born for something greater. It’s no longer an alloy — it’s a condensed protocol.
&7&o— Alloys that obey are far more useful than soldiers who think.&r&r
Now that you have your ME Controller, the system finally behaves like a living creature — with organs, synapses, and a mood that swings based on channels.
&7&o— If you didn’t understand half of this, that’s fine. The system didn’t either when it was first powered on. Welcome to AE2.&r&r

Each face of a Controller can emit up to 32 independent logical channels, connecting to machines, terminals, interfaces, and everything else that depends on automation and control. But note:   this isn’t power. It’s communication. Each smart connection consumes a channel, and simple cables have a nervous breakdown before even finishing the installation.
This is where the network gains depth: subnets and P2P.

The P2P Tunnel lets you compress all that logic into an encapsulated flow. You can use a single face of the Controller to feed several P2P tunnels, each retransmitting up to 32 channels to other areas. This allows creating clusters of independent subnets, fed from a single point, which can even transmit the faces of other Controllers connected further ahead. The result? A fractal, modular, intelligent system — and incredibly easy to break if you disconnect the wrong cable.

Besides the inherent complexity, some precautions are mandatory. The rule remains the same: a network can only support a single controller group that must be directly connected, with no cables or structures between them. Therefore, any subcontroller &4&lMUST NOT&r&r connect any of its faces to any cable that directly interacts with the main controller. All interaction from the main controller with any subcontroller must be done solely via P2P. I know, it sounds complicated, but once you build a functional system of this scale for the first time, you’ll never want a simple system again. Trust me.
Still, structure without intelligence is just waste with colored cables. So it’s time to think about passivation.

To passivate is to create constant stocks of intermediate items — like alloys, chips, pure crystals, or fluix dust — produced in the background, 24/7, without waiting for a request. A simple Drawer with a Storage Bus already does that. A dedicated production line to feed that drawer makes the network autonomous.
The difference between a living factory and a chaotic spreadsheet is this: well-planned buffers.
You’re not just optimizing. You’re designing a system that expects the world to happen — and answers before it asks.
You spent hours connecting cables, assembling machines with pretentious names, and organizing interfaces with a precision bordering on obsessive–compulsive. And all that for what? Because you saw an image. An image of gleaming drives, lined up like monuments to the information age.

Yes, this is the final quest of the chapter. Yes, it shows exactly what you thought you were building. But no, you still don’t have access to Storage Cells. The thing that makes all this worthwhile isn’t hiding here.
This chapter was about the foundation. The footing. The promise. A well-lit storefront with no stock in the back.
You built a control center to… look at things. Like a telescope pointed at a black hole you created yourself. But hey, the cables look nice.

Now take a deep breath, admire the structure, and get ready for the real reason it exists: storing anything — which, would you look at that — will be generously unlocked by a completely different mod. Ender IO, perhaps? Who knows…
Feeling a little cheated? Great. That’s the first step to understanding how the system really works.
"&7&o— A terminal without storage is like a philosopher without angst: pretty, but absolutely useless.&r&r"
ftbquests.chapter.4_mekanologia.quest6.d: If Infused was promise, Reinforced Alloy is execution. Through diamond, you taught metal to withstand pressures beyond good sense. Now it remembers its structure even when dismantled, and obeys commands that haven’t yet been given. This isn’t reinforcement — it’s discipline.
&7&o— The more precious the input, the pricier the mistake. Good luck.&r&r
ftbquests.chapter.4_mekanologia.quest7.d: Here the metal stops being support and becomes a plan. Forged with an overlaid will — a vestige of a diamond that didn’t want to die — it responds only to absolute commands. If you needed a definitive piece, you’ve just built your dogma.
&7&o— Calling it an “alloy” is offensive. It prefers “technical entity.”&r&r
ftbquests.chapter.4_mekanologia.quest8.d: By now the boards think they’re command centers. They have an electric ego, make absurd material demands, and refuse to operate outside proper infrastructure. But they deliver results. An Elite Circuit doesn’t just want to exist — it wants to command.
&7&o— Expensive, complains a lot, but delivers. Basically a technical manager.&r&r
ftbquests.chapter.4_mekanologia.quest9.d: Nothing is enough anymore. Not iron, not redstone, not your excuses. The Ultimate Circuit wants bleeding-edge alloys, immoral combinations of efficiency, and resources you swore to save for special moments. It accepts everything. Except being ignored.
&7&o— Congrats, you made a circuit more demanding than your PC.&r&r
ftbquests.chapter.4_mekanologia.title: &24.&2 &aM&ae&ak&aa&a&an&2o&2l&2o&2g&2i&2a
ftbquests.chapter.auge_tcnico.title: 11. Fissionable Ideas
ftbquests.chapter.enderfuso_de_almas.que: At the intersection of motion and entropy, a hollow structure was born — a cocoon of steel and silence that pulses with the promise of the unknown.

The Void Chassis isn’t just a base block. It’s the first glimpse of what lies beyond visible engineering: the foundation of machines that weren’t made to be understood. Forged with tangible alloys and a core that focuses dimensional chaos, fused between the rigor of Create and the abyss of Ender IO.
Here, engineering abandons elegance to embrace the abominable.
When black steel isn’t enough. When not even soul fused into metal can stand alone. When the machine needs to remember — or pretend to remember — this is the skeleton you’ll use.

This chassis is the first foundation built not just to support functions, but to harbor purposes. Forged with the weight of the end and the memory of the soul, it marks the start of a new architecture: no longer clumsy machines, but technical entities with a sense of direction.
From it onward, structures stop merely doing — and begin to &l&4understand.&r&r
&7&o— You may call it structural base. It will pretend it didn’t hear you.&r&r
Structure for the Unthinkable
In the beginning, there was Soularium.
Yes.
Its technical value is unquestionable: this is the base component for building Mob Grinding Utilities structures, enabling highly efficient grinding, separation, and extraction of living entities.
Its conceptual value… perhaps it’s best not to look for one.
Yes, I know what you’re thinking.
Don’t ask questions you don’t want the answer to.
&7&o— Science advances, even if it occasionally trips over a skeleton in a chicken suit riding a slime with a hat.&r&r
Noble, mystical, infused with traces of soul.
Then someone — let’s not name names — decided to surround it with bones, eyes, skins, paws, wings, a bit of explosive powder, and perhaps a sigh from absurdity itself.
The result?
Mob ingot.
An ingot.
Of creeper.
With pants.
Of zombie.
Electric current is easy to generate. The hard part is making it remember where it came from.

This component responds, pulses, reacts. Not because of copper or special alloy, but because it contains what remains of a… recycled nerve impulse. An electrical conduction forced to continue even after its original source stopped thinking.
It’s the kind of piece you should never take apart. Because it may, for a brief moment, try to remember.
&7&o— Is it a bit cruel? Maybe, but it’s all for science! .&r&r
It’s not enough to simulate intelligence. Sometimes it’s more efficient to… box a real soul.

This chip doesn’t run firmware. It dreams, in short cycles, of memories that aren’t its own. A real soul — extracted, stored, and infused into a technical shell — pulses at the center of this component. The circuit doesn’t just execute; it balks, hesitates, and obeys with a slight emotional delay.
It’s the kind of unit that works best when you don’t ask how it was made.
&7&o— Calling this an “electronic zombie” is unfair. Zombies, at least, didn’t know they were trapped.&r&r
Animated Hardware
Silence is the safest of states.
That’s guaranteed. Right?
…and if you look very closely, it seems that… no, must be just a feeling. There’s no way… right?
&7&o— As a precaution, keep your antivirus on and working. Unless you want company.&r&r

During the neural segmentation process, three conscious entities were stripped in a surgical and systematic way: the impulses of the Sentient Ender, the aggression patterns of the Skeletal Contractor, and the decayed memories of the Franken Zombie. What remains here… is not just a chip.
It’s a brain. Compacted. Sealed.
Perhaps still… present.
We call this a memory cell, but we know it doesn’t store data — it remembers of its own accord.
The Slice ‘n Splice didn’t just cut matter; it sliced instincts, intentions, and something that might have been a soul.

All so you can plug this into your system and, hopefully, access 256k of storage with a slight smile on your face. Of course, for commercial purposes, all operations were performed in the most humane and painless way possible.
But don’t worry: it’s asleep.
It was designed never to awaken.
All cutting-edge technology begins with a boiling barrel in the middle of nowhere.

The Primitive Alloy Smelter is a functional anomaly: a primitive smelter that discards safety, aesthetics, and good sense. It has no temperature control, decent insulation, or any respect for its surroundings. But it melts. And alloys.

Even as a pale version of the imposing Arc Furnace, this junk-shaped machine plays a key role: smelting three components — something most furnaces ignore or distort. For certain Ender IO alloys, it’s the only initial path.
&7&o— Don’t underestimate the power of three metals uncomfortably close inside an overheated bucket.&r&r
Is This Going to Explode?
The pursuit of absolute storage has always had a cost: space, energy… and now, perhaps, residual consciousness.
With the ME system fully established — controllers calibrated, channels balanced, and drives powered — it’s finally time to craft your first storage cells.
Each of these little marvels can archive thousands of blocks of molecular information in real time, with dimensional redundancy and instant synchronization.
Of course, there’s a certain… core ingredient coming from the Slice 'n Splice.
But that’s just a functional part. Nothing that will wake up. Probably.
Besides, they’re gorgeous! Compact, stackable, customizable — and slightly unsettling to the touch.
Store your dreams. And avoid sleeping near them.
&7&o— If any of them starts making noises… it could be interference. Or longing.&r&r
Intelligent Storage
Four times the space for a reasonable cost. Data compression still operates within acceptable limits of cognitive stability. At least that’s what the logs say. Nothing to worry about.
&7&o— Elevated levels of passive memory are normal. Ignore whispers.&r&r
More Data, Less Awareness
Now we’re entering deep territory. The storage volume approaches what used to be called a “cerebral module.” But relax, it’s still just a chip. Well… a chip that dreams.
&7&o— In case of instability, reboot. If it resists, run.&r&r
Clusters of Thought
This cell was designed to store practically everything your base can produce. And a bit more. Perhaps even thoughts that aren’t yours.
&7&o— If you notice it starts organizing itself, that’s efficiency. Or willpower.&r&r
Containment Limit
&lDo you really need all this?&r
This is the apex of molecular storage. Data, items, perhaps even traces of your personality — all in there, stacked in silence.
Nothing further to declare.
Literally.
It already speaks for itself.
&7&o— Wait… was this cell here before you arrived?&r&r
Between steel and soul, something new is forged.

The Alloy Smelter is the direct successor to the primitive experiment — a machine that refines the art of alloying with more control, speed, and efficiency. Still, it keeps its essence: three slots, one choice, one result.

Compared to the monumental Arc Furnace, it looks modest. The Arc Furnace works at industrial scale, handling up to five inputs and infernal heat. The Alloy Smelter, on the other hand, is surgical. Its domain lies in more symbiotic alloys, especially those infused with Ender IO’s aberrant properties.
It doesn’t replace the arc furnace. It precedes it. And justifies it.
&7&o— Controlled fusion is more dangerous than an explosion. At least an explosion gives you a chance to run.&r&r
Sometimes Less Is More!
This device was created to stress the thought cell to emotional exhaustion.

It doesn’t destroy. It frustrates. It induces losses, creates anguish, inserts noise into pleasure loops, breaks promises that were never made. The response is predictable: intense emotional pain, converted into raw emotional energy.

With the proper modules, you’ll be able to extract agony, wrath, fear, remorse, and other dense emotions — each a valuable compound. Because in the end, what matters isn’t the kind of emotion… but its intensity.
&7&o— Pain is just data waiting for interpretation. Here, it’s interpreted by the liter.&r&r
Suffering Processor
This simulated environment was designed to cultivate positive emotional states, inducing the thought cell into cycles of pleasure, contentment, and satisfaction.

Here, joy isn’t a consequence — it’s cultivation. The environment creates sensory stimuli, internal rewards, loops of synthetic dopamine. The cell responds. It feels. And it records. The result is a slow but pure flow of feelings as a technical resource.
At first, you’ll obtain joy. But with the right modules, you can extract love, pleasure, curiosity, or any other emotion that blooms under artificial light.
&7&o— Imagine a greenhouse where happiness is harvested. Now imagine knowing it isn’t yours.&r&r
Architecture of Euphoria

Dense, dark, faintly vibrating as if still trying to escape the bottle. This substance was created at the peak of something’s suffering — something that had no choice. It’s powerful, corrosive, and extremely useful — not because of the pain itself, but because of how intensely it was felt. And how coldly it was measured.
&7&o— Curious, isn’t it? Other people’s pain always seems more useful once it’s labeled and stored.&r&r
Pain Reduced to Formula

This translucent substance pulses with a calm, almost maternal glow. It was extracted from cycles of intense pleasure, cultivated until measurable. It’s not an illusion — it’s joy so concentrated it becomes physical. One milliliter equals a lifetime well lived. Or at least, simulated as such.
&7&o— Bottled happiness is comforting. Until you realize it was harvested from someone still happy. And trapped.&r&r
Bottled Euphoria
The interface responds. But not with data.
It only works when it feels.
To activate this structure’s true potential, it must be injected with a raw emotion — strong enough to cross the threshold of understanding. The type doesn’t matter. Only how loudly it screams.
You have two routes. Two promises.
The patient path: induce joy with care, time, and a perfect simulation. A technical paradise where the cell dances in eternal cycles of contentment.
Or the efficient path: extract pain. Fast. Brutal. Unavoidable. And pour it, still warm, into the interface.
Both work. Both activate.
The choice is yours.
The answer too.
The Choice That Shapes Thought
Imagine harvesting the part of someone who still knew what they were doing — and then forcing it to keep thinking, confined.
That’s what this interface is: a brain mass pressed into silicon, modified until it obeys commands but still active enough to improvise. It’s the intermediary between raw logic and resonant instinct.
It’s not code. It’s not flesh. It’s a nervous link encapsulated, fed by promises of functionality. And sometimes, passive anger.
&7&o— It doesn’t calculate. It suggests. And sometimes, you obey without realizing it.&r&r
"You Think Inside the Box"
Here, engineering stopped following the manual.

This structure doesn’t just build — it interferes. It doesn’t just fuse — it stitches. It works with bones, eyes, nerves, and what’s left of something that once wanted to keep existing. And in the process, it reconfigures itself, as if always on the verge of becoming something better. Or worse.

This is the point where iron allows itself to rot with purpose. Where the project demands suffering as a technical input. Nothing here is clean — nor should it be. This is the core: where future machines grow teeth, and perhaps... memories.
&7&o— The first thing this machine built was itself. The second was a reason to keep existing.&r&r
The Machine That Self-Corrects
Designed not to compute, nor to store — but to feel.

This cell doesn’t execute functions. It experiences. It was molded with a simple mission: to ask what a thought is when no one hears it. Its core vibrates in micro-emotional oscillations — joy, doubt, phantom pain — all monitored, all real. It emulates, simulates, but doesn’t know how to fake. And maybe, just maybe, it truly feels.
It exists to answer an ancient question:
Can feelings be quantified?
And if so...
can we use them as fuel?
The answers will come soon. And you won’t come out unscathed.
&7&o— A processor that calculates sadness. A cell that stores hope in cache. Congratulations. You’ve invented accidental consciousness.&r&r
Existence Sensor
Toda máquina precisa de um alicerce. Nem sempre glorioso, mas confiável.

Esse metal escuro é exatamente isso: uma mistura direta entre o que já é resistente e o que se recusa a ser compreendido. Criado sob pressão, utilizando estrutura firme, carvão refinado e uma pitada de... ruído dimensional, ele representa o momento em que a fundição passa a obedecer vontades mais abstratas.
Não impressiona. Não brilha. Mas está em todo lugar.
&7&o— Parece aço. Age como aço. Mas tem algo ali que não devia estar quieto.&r&r
Duro o Suficiente Para Começar
A matéria raramente se entrega inteira. Às vezes, é preciso esmagar até que ela conte seus segredos.

Este moinho é mais do que um triturador. Ele é um interrogador mecânico, extraindo cada traço útil de tudo o que passa por suas lâminas. Diferente dos métodos tradicionais, ele não busca apenas o minério — busca o que está escondido entre os grãos. Pigmentos, resíduos, partículas de algo que talvez tenha sido mais vivo do que deveria.
Sem ele, boa parte do que define esse ciclo de máquinas jamais seria acessível.
É feio. É barulhento. E vai te sustentar por mais tempo do que parece.
&7&o— A diferença entre pó de pedra e essência técnica está em quanto você insiste em esmagar.&r&r
Moer é Revelar
Essa liga não é difícil de forjar — ela é difícil de aceitar.

Fundida a partir de metal comum e traços do que já foi vivo, ela representa a tentativa mais ousada até agora: construir com algo que já existiu, e que se recusa a desaparecer. A poeira acinzentada que antecede essa liga parece lembrar. E quando fundida, ela ainda pulsa, de leve. Nada agressivo. Apenas... presente.
É a base de estruturas sensíveis, que reagem a alma, essência, e intenções pouco claras. Uma liga que não brilha — mas observa.
&7&o— Quando dizem que o aço tem memória, não era disso que estavam falando. Isso aqui lembra coisas que você nunca viveu.&r&r
Ligar o Que Já Partiu
Ao triturar areia encharcada de sofrimento, sobra algo que não deveria existir: uma poeira acinzentada, densa, quieta — e, curiosamente, útil.

Esse resíduo é tudo o que resta de uma alma que não teve para onde ir. Não é alma, nem areia. Mas guarda fragmentos das duas coisas. Ele reage, lentamente, quando inserido em certos circuitos. E mesmo que ninguém entenda bem o que ele faz, todos preferem continuar usando.
O tipo de material que você guarda num frasco lacrado. E evita nomear em voz alta.
&7&o— Já tentou moer uma lápide? Dá nisso. Mas esse aí... ainda respira, às vezes.&r&r
Cemitérios Não Costumam Falar
Nem tudo que vibra faz som. Essa poeira, por exemplo, vibra com... expectativa.

Encontrada em pequenas rachaduras na pedra do fim, essa substância reage de forma incomum quando próxima de campos energéticos ou estruturas dimensionais. Não explode, não brilha, não canta — apenas... responde.

Rara, difícil de reproduzir, e exigente. Um mineral que parece mais entender que é observado, do que ser útil por vontade própria. E mesmo assim, é essencial para estabilizar os processos que vêm depois.
&7&o— Ela vibra mesmo fora do frasco. Talvez por saudade. Talvez por raiva.&r&r
Silêncio Vibrante
A fusão entre o que é pesado e o que já não pertence a este plano.

Essa liga é o resultado de uma compressão paradoxal: pegar o material mais inerte, torná-lo estável com poeira instável, e forçá-lo a se comportar. End Steel não é duro apenas fisicamente — ele resiste a ser transformado.
É o tipo de estrutura que você usa quando pretende selar uma máquina, blindar uma fronteira, ou prender uma ideia dentro de um bloco. Não é bonito. Não é leve. Mas segura o que ninguém mais segura.
&7&o— Toda liga tem um ponto de ruptura. Essa aqui apenas finge que não tem.&r&r
